comments.body: Why have the `|default('0.0')` when it seems like `or '0.0'` is working for the api version example

The difference is that if `docker version` fails, `docker_cli_version_stdout.stdout` isn't there and `docker_cli_version_stdout.stdout or '0.0'` fails. I had to change it to `docker_cli_version_stdout.stdout | default('0.0')` to stop failing (this happens for centos/6). The `or '0.0'` is there to make sure the result is not an empty string (which could happen if the command does not fail, but outputs an empty string for whatever reason).

(The API and docker-py version checks always have `stdout` in the result, since the Python interpreter can be called. In case `docker` is not installed, like on centos/6, there's no `stdout` and `|default` is needed.)

Ahh ok makes sense, seems like this line and the below ones could be simplified with `variable.stdout | default('0.0', True)`. The second arg means the default value is used when the value is evaluated to False like an empty string or `0` http://jinja.pocoo.org/docs/2.10/templates/#default.
Ah, that's good to know. I won't change the two lines below, though, since if `stdout` isn't there, something went really bad (Python interpreter not found) and the test deserves to die :)

Hmm, that didn't work; see [here](https://app.shippable.com/github/ansible/ansible/runs/100827/47/console) for the shippable output. Here's what I tried to do:
```.diff
-        docker_cli_version: "{{ (docker_cli_version_stdout.stdout | default('0.0')) or '0.0' }}"
+        docker_cli_version: "{{ docker_cli_version_stdout.stdout | default('0.0', true) }}"
```
I'll remove the last commit.
Hmm ok, I tested something similar locally but obviously not enough. Thanks for trying.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +36,40 @@
    - set_fact:
        docker_cli_version: "{{ (docker_cli_version_stdout.stdout | default('0.0')) or '0.0' }}"
        docker_api_version: "{{ docker_api_version_stdout.stdout or '0.0' }}"
        docker_py_version: "{{ docker_py_version_stdout.stdout or '0.0' }}"
